sect1.title: CASE 54
sect1.para: The patient was a male in his late 60s with prior 5-month hospitalization for severe COVID-19 pneumonia followed by a stay at a long-term acute care hospital. His history was significant for type 2 diabetes, coronary artery disease, hypertension, chronic kidney disease requiring hemodialysis, ventilator-dependent respiratory failure, and a chronic sacral ulcer requiring debridement. Most recently he was admitted to the medical intensive care unit with septic shock and aspiration pneumonia, with an extended and complicated hospital course with numerous infections.

listitem.para: 1. What hospital-acquired infections (HAIs) was the patient at risk of developing?

sect1.para: Presently, the patient was found to have new right upper lobe infiltrates and acute leukocytosis (white blood cell count, 30,400/μl). The patient was also noted to have pyuria, and the subsequent urine culture grew ≥105 CFU/ml of a yeast.

listitem.para: 2. How should yeast from a urine culture be reported? Is there any additional work that should be done given this particular patient’s risk factors?
3. What is Candida auris, and why is it an infection prevention concern?
4. What risk factors are associated with C. auris colonization?
5. What methods exist for screening patients for C. auris colonization?

sect1.para: The patient was treated with caspofungin for 10 days for suspected funguria and with cefiderocol for 7 days for possible hospital-acquired pneumonia given the history of multidrug-resistant respiratory pathogens. After nearly 2 months without antimicrobials, the patient again had pyuria and repeat urine culture growing ≥105 CFU/ml of C. auris. Two days later, blood cultures were positive and the Gram stain from the culture bottle showed the morphology in Fig. 54.1.

listitem.para: 6. What Gram stain morphology is seen in Fig. 54.1?

figure.title: Figure 54.1 Gram stain from blood culture bottle (magnification, ×1,000).

textobject.para: A microscopic photograph showing clusters of dark-stained filamentous structures, possibly representing fungal hyphae or bacterial colonies, with branching patterns against a light background.

sect1.para: The yeast was identified as C. auris by matrix-assisted laser desorption ionization–time of flight mass spectrometry (MALDI-TOF MS).

listitem.para: 7. Is this a reliable method for C. auris identification? What known challenges exist with C. auris identification with other methods?
8. Broadly, what is the expected C. auris susceptibility profile?

sect1.para: This patient’s C. auris isolate was tested against fluconazole (MIC >64 μg/ml, R) and micafungin as a surrogate for caspofungin (MIC 0.06 μg/ml, S) using a CLSI-recommended broth microdilution method. Unfortunately, the patient ultimately passed away.

1.This patient’s critical illness, number of invasive procedures including ventilator dependence and number of indwelling lines (e. g., central venous catheter), and various antibiotic courses are risk factors for HAIs. Specifically, this patient’s lifesaving interventions present the risk for ventilator-associated pneumonia, central line-associated bloodstream infection, catheter-associated urinary tract infection, and surgical site infection. This patient was also at risk of developing Clostridioides difficile infection due to recent antibiotic exposure, age (≥65), and extensive contact with health care (1).

2. It is recommended that Candida species are not reported specifically and instead reported as “yeast” with further identification only by request (2). However, Cryptococcus, Geotrichum, and Trichosporon recovered from urine cultures should be reported to at least the genus level. Antifungal susceptibility testing is not routinely performed when yeasts are isolated from urine. While non-auris Candida species may not be reported clinically from nonsterile culture sites, identifying yeast isolates to “passively screen” for C. auris can be a beneficial infection prevention tool, particularly for inpatients (3).

3. C. auris is a yeast that has emerged as a global health threat over the course of the last decade and may be multidrug resistant. The first documented isolation of C. auris occurred in 2009 in Japan (4). Since then, it has been isolated all over the globe, with the first reported U. S. case occurring in New York(5). In 2023, there were more than 4,500 documented clinical cases of C. auris, with Nevada, California, Florida, New York, Illinois, and Texas reporting the most (6). The rapid rise and immediate threat of C. auris have been noted in the 2019 CDC Antibiotic Resistance Threats Report and the 2022 WHO Fungal Priority List (7, 8). It has been postulated that the emergence of C. auris as a pathogen is a result of global warming (9). With the adaptation of C. auris to rising temperatures in its natural habitat, it acquired a tolerance to animal body temperature, which resulted in the ability to colonize and spread in new populations. C. auris is most closely related to C. duobushaemulonii, C. pseudohaemulonii, and C. haemulonii, all rarely encountered Candida species of limited pathogenic potential (10). There are five recognized clades of C. auris, emerging from distinct geographic regions, all of which have been detected in the United States. Clade I is the most commonly encountered in the United States, but local outbreaks are largely dependent on the mode of introduction (11).

C. auris presents a significant infection prevention concern due to its unique abilities to persist in the hospital environment and resist disinfection. Studies have shown that C. auris can remain viable on surfaces for weeks (12). Additionally, C. auris can be resistant to commonly used disinfection products, including quaternary ammonia compounds. Recommendations for disinfection include the use of products on the Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) list “P” (13), which are products with specific claims for activity against C. auris(e. g., containing sodium hypochlorite, hydrogen peroxide) or, if unavailable, EPA list “K” with C. difficilespore activity (e. g., containing sodium hypochlorite, hydrogen peroxide)(14). Together, these features of C. auris contribute to the possibility of environment-to-patient transmission within the health care facility.

4. Risk factors for C. auris colonization include a known epidemiological link to a patient infected with C. auris, admission at a facility with known C. auris circulation, or frequent contact with health care, specifically long-term acute care facilities or ventilator-capable skilled nursing facilities (15). Invasive procedures or lifesaving measures, such as indwelling medical devices or central lines, increase the risk of infection. Colonization with C. auris increases the risk that patients will progress to invasive infection (16).

5. CDC recommends screening patients with the risk factors described in answer 4 for C. auris colonization (15). Identification of colonized patients can be helpful in implementing the correct infection prevention control measures, namely contact precautions, and directing C. auris-specific terminal cleaning of the patient room. Active surveillance for C. auris colonization can be done by culture or nucleic acid amplification test (NAAT) (17). A combined swab of the axilla and groin can be plated directly to a salt/dulcitol-containing agar or enriched in a salt/dulcitol broth prior to plating. These conditions selectively grow C. auris over other Candidaspecies. Chromogenic media, e. g., CHROMagar Candida Plus, can also be used for isolation and differentiation of Candida species, including C. auris. NAAT testing uses the same sample type and is preferred to culture in terms of speed and throughput. Broth preenrichment can improve sensitivity of NAAT screening.
6. Figure 54.1 shows small oval budding yeasts in the Gram stain from the blood culture bottles. This morphology is most consistent with Candida species.

7. MALDI-TOF MS is a reliable method for identification of C. auris when using up-to-date databases. Misidentification of C. auris as other yeast species has been reported when using other semiautomated or phenotypic identification methods (18). Molecular methods, such as rapid blood culture yeast identification panels and 28S D1/D2 or internal transcribed spacer sequencing, have been shown to be reliable as well. Special chromogenic agars with the ability to differentiate C. auris can provide rapid, culture-based discrimination.

8. Azole resistance of C. auris is extremely common, >90%, and azoles are considered ineffective (19). Resistance to amphotericin B is also common, particularly in clade I, the most common clade encountered in the United States. Resistance to echinocandins is infrequent, but pan-resistant isolates have been reported. There are currently no established interpretive criteria of antifungal susceptibility testing for C. auris. Tentative breakpoints, based on criteria used for other Candida species, may be used to interpret MICs and assist in choice of therapy (20).

listitem.para: C. auris is an emerging global pathogen, with dramatically increased case counts over the last decade.

Prolonged contact with health care, stays at long-term acute care hospitals or ventilator-capable skilled nursing facilities, invasive procedures or indwelling devices, receipt of broad-spectrum antimicrobials, or prolonged exposure to fluconazole have been linked to increased risk of C. auris colonization.
Screening is recommended upon hospitalization to direct infection prevention practices. Screening can be accomplished by NAAT and culture.
C. auris risk to the health care facility includes prolonged survival on surfaces and resistance to disinfection, contributing to the possibility of hospital-acquired infections.
Colonization with C. auris increases the risk of serious infection, particularly in immunocompromised patients. Infection with C. auris carries a high mortality rate.

C. auris has high rates of resistance to azoles and shows variable resistance to amphotericin and low-level resistance to echinocandins. Pan-resistant isolates have been detected in the United States.
